The Unruh Quantum Otto Engine

Enrique Arias, b ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Thiago R. de Oliveira b ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ M. S. Sarandy earias@iprj.uerj.br tro@if.uff.br msarandy@id.uff.br
Abstract

We introduce a quantum heat engine performing an Otto cycle by using the thermal properties of the quantum vacuum. Since Hawking and Unruh, it has been established that the vacuum space, either near a black hole or for an accelerated observer, behaves as a bath of thermal radiation. In this work, we present a fully quantum Otto cycle, which relies on the Unruh effect for a single quantum bit (qubit) in contact with quantum vacuum fluctuations. By using the notions of quantum thermodynamics and perturbation theory we obtain that the quantum vacuum can exchange heat and produce work on the qubit. Moreover, we obtain the efficiency and derive the conditions to have both a thermodynamic and a kinematic cycle in terms of the initial populations of the excited state, which define a range of allowed accelerations for the Unruh engine.

Keywords:
Quantum thermodynamics, Unruh effect, Black hole physics.

1 Introduction

There has been renewed interest in the investigation of the thermodynamics of quantum systems, namely, quantum thermodynamics¬†Gemmer:book . A great deal of effort has been devoted to the foundations of the theory, with general discussions about the derivation of the second law in the quantum realm or even the whole theory of thermodynamics from quantum information theory¬†Goold16 . There is also intense focus on quantum heat engines, Maxwell demons, and advantages of work extraction by global operations over quantum systems¬†Maruyama:09 . Even though the first works in this direction appeared already in the 1950‚Äôs Scovil59 , it regained interest through the works by Kieu¬†Kieu04 ; Kieu06 , where a quantum heat engine is proposed by using as working substance a single two-level system, i.e, a quantum bit (qubit). There, it has been analyzed the quantum Otto cycle, which is the quantum generalization of the classical prototype model of combustion engines. The Otto cycle is composed of two adiabatic and two isochoric steps operating between a hot and a cold reservoir. In order for the machine to produce a finite amount of work, one needs to fulfill the condition TH>(Œî2/Œî1)‚ÄãTCsubscriptùëáùêªsubscriptŒî2subscriptŒî1subscriptùëáùê∂T_{H}>(\Delta_{2}/\Delta_{1})T_{C}, with THsubscriptùëáùêªT_{H} (TCsubscriptùëáùê∂T_{C}) the temperature of the hot (cold) reservoir and Œî1subscriptŒî1\Delta_{1} and Œî2subscriptŒî2\Delta_{2} the energy gaps in the qubit Hamiltonian spectrum before and after the adiabatic expansion, respectively. Therefore, for quantum systems, the classical inequality TH>TCsubscriptùëáùêªsubscriptùëáùê∂T_{H}>T_{C} has been shown to be insufficient for a heat engine to produce work in individual thermodynamic cycles. Another possibility considered in Refs.¬†Kieu04 ; Kieu06 is to use a gas of bosons as the thermal reservoir and let the interaction with the system to last a finite time, such that the system does not fully equilibrate with the reservoir. In that case, a cycle can be built by suitably adjusting the initial population of the excited state.These works have been generalized to include different models for the reservoir and also for more complex working substances, e.g. coupled qubits, where quantum correlations such as entanglement may improve the thermal efficiency¬†Zhang:07 ; Zhang:08 ; Wang:09 .

On the other hand, the relation between quantum thermodynamics, relativistic quantum mechanics, and black hole physics remains little explored. The standard thermodynamics of black holes has been elucidated a long time ago bardeen1973 , with striking results such as the Bekenstein-Hawking entropy area law¬†bekenstein1973 and Hawking radiation¬†hawking1974 ; hawking1975 ; hawking1976 . In this scenario, relativistic effects in quantum thermodynamics may lead to fruitful directions. A particularly relevant phenomenon is the Unruh effect and its implications to the domain of quantum thermodynamics. The Unruh effect predicts the existence of thermal properties to the vacuum state of a quantum field. More specifically, it establishes that the quantum vacuum fluctuations with respect to an accelerated observer in flat space-time exhibit thermal properties with temperature proportional to the observer acceleration birrell ; unruh1976 . Even though an experimental realization of the Unruh effect remains as a challenge, it has recently appeared a number of proposals of physical observations, such as in superconducting qubits¬†Felicetti:15 , ion traps¬†Laguna:17 , quantum metrology¬†Wang:14 , oscillating neutrinos¬†Ahluwalia:16 , and classical electrodynamics¬†Cozzella:17 (see also Ref.¬†Crispino:08 for other previous proposals). Here, our aim is to exploit the thermal properties of the vacuum fluctuations predicted by the Unruh effect to model a thermal reservoir and define a relativistic quantum heat engine. We consider as working substance a single qubit linearly coupled to a quantum field prepared in its vacuum state. This is the model used by Unruh and DeWitt in order to detect the quantum vacuum fluctuations effects¬†unruh1976 ; dewitt1979 . The Unruh quantum thermodynamical cycle proposed in our work consists of a series of quantum adiabatic and isochoric processes. During the adiabatic processes, we consider that the qubit undergoes an expansion/contraction of its energy gap due to the influence of some external field. Since the processes are adiabatic, there is no heat exchange between the qubit and the environment. However, the adiabatic expansion/contraction would cost/produce some amount of work. On the other hand, the isochoric processes are defined here by coupling the qubit to the quantum vacuum and considering two different constant accelerations for the qubit at these stages. In this manner, due to the Unruh effect, the qubit would feel the vacuum as a thermal reservoir, with no work at this stage. Heat and work are provided by the prescriptions of quantum thermodynamics and are find using a perturbation theory approach in the coupling constant between the qubit and the quantum field. In order to run as a thermal machine, we must also consider the conditions for a closed trajectory of the qubit in real space, since we are dealing with simultaneously thermodynamic and kinematic cycles. The cycle conditions are then derived in terms of the initial populations of the excited state, which define a range of allowed acceleration pairs for the Unruh quantum engine. Throughout the paper, we will adopt natural units, such that the speed of light cùëêc, the Planck constant ‚ÑèPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar, and the Boltzmann constant kBsubscriptùëòùêµk_{B} are taken as c=‚Ñè=kB=1ùëêPlanck-constant-over-2-pisubscriptùëòùêµ1c=\hbar=k_{B}=1.

2 Quantum Otto engine

It is worth observing here that the notion of heat in the quantum thermodynamics domain is entirely compatible with the notions of Boltzmann entropy S=‚àíTr‚Äã(œÅ‚Äãln‚Å°œÅ)ùëÜTrùúåùúåS=-\text{Tr}\left(\rho\ln\rho\right) and that of Boltzmann distribution at equilibrium œÅ=e‚àí‚Ñã/T/Zùúåsuperscriptùëí‚Ñãùëáùëç\rho=e^{-{\cal H}/T}/Z, where ZùëçZ is a normalization constant and TùëáT is the temperature of the system. We now briefly review the Otto quantum engine first proposed in Ref.¬†Kieu04 . The classical Otto cycle is composed of two adiabatic processes together with two isochoric processes, which is common in automobile piston engines. In its quantum version, the working substance is a quantum system instead of an ideal gas. Here, we adopt the simplest quantum system, namely, a qubit. The two adiabatic processes, which in the classical engine are provided by the adiabatic expansion and contraction of a piston, here are adiabatic increase and decrease of the upper energy level of the qubit, respectively. The two isochoric process of the classical case are replaced in the quantum version by keeping the system with constant gaps while in contact with a thermal reservoir, which implies in vanishing work.

Let us now consider a single qubit with eigenlevels {|e‚ü©,|g‚ü©}ketùëíketùëî\{|e\rangle,|g\rangle\}, which are associated with energies {œâ,0}ùúî0\{\omega,0\}, respectively. Hence, by applying the spectral theorem¬†Horn:13 , the qubit Hamiltonian can be written as ‚Ñã=œâ‚Äã|e‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®e|‚Ñãùúîketùëíbraùëí{\cal H}=\omega\,|e\rangle\langle e|. In our cycle we consider that, during an adiabatic process, the energy level œâùúî\omega changes. This change could be caused by some external field or changes in the external conditions as the size of the recipient where the qubit is confined. Here, we only assume it can be done in a smooth way such that the quantum adiabatic theorem is valid¬†Born:28 ; Kato:50 ; Messiah:book . The four stages of a quantum Otto cycle are

  • ‚Ä¢

    (i) The qubit begins at the initial state œÅi‚Äãn=p‚Äã|e‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®e|+(1‚àíp)|g‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®g|subscriptùúåùëñùëõùëùketùëíquantum-operator-productùëí1ùëùùëîbraùëî\rho_{in}=p|e\rangle\langle e|+(1-p)|g\rangle\langle g| with an energy gap œâ1subscriptùúî1\omega_{1} and undergoes an adiabatic expansion to a larger value œâ2subscriptùúî2\omega_{2}. This expansion is at the cost of some work over the system. On the other hand, since the process is adiabatic, no heat is exchanged with the environment.

  • ‚Ä¢

    (ii) The qubit in the state œÅi‚Äãnsubscriptùúåùëñùëõ\rho_{in} and with fixed energy gap œâ2subscriptùúî2\omega_{2} is put in contact with a hot bath at temperature THsubscriptùëáùêªT_{H}. After some interaction time ùíØ2subscriptùíØ2{\cal T}_{2}, the qubit ends up at the state œÅ=(p+Œ¥‚ÄãpH)‚Äã|e‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®e|+(1‚àíp‚àíŒ¥‚ÄãpH)|g‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®g|ùúåùëùùõøsubscriptùëùùêªketùëíquantum-operator-productùëí1ùëùùõøsubscriptùëùùêªùëîbraùëî\rho=(p+\delta p_{H})|e\rangle\langle e|+(1-p-\delta p_{H})|g\rangle\langle g|. Only heat is transfered in this process, with no work performed.

  • ‚Ä¢

    (iii) The qubit at the state œÅùúå\rho is isolated from the hot bath and undergoes an adiabatic compression, which reduces its energy gap from œâ2subscriptùúî2\omega_{2} to œâ1subscriptùúî1\omega_{1}. This process is adiabatic, with no change in the populations of the energy levels. Thus, work is performed by the system, with no heat transfered.

  • ‚Ä¢

    (iv) The qubit still with the state œÅùúå\rho is put in contact with a cold reservoir at temperature TCsubscriptùëáùê∂T_{C}. After some interaction time ùíØ1subscriptùíØ1{\cal T}_{1}, the qubit ends up at the final state œÅf‚Äãi‚Äãn=(p+Œ¥‚ÄãpH+Œ¥‚ÄãpC)‚Äã|e‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®e|+(1‚àíp‚àíŒ¥‚ÄãpH‚àíŒ¥‚ÄãpC)|g‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®g|subscriptùúåùëìùëñùëõùëùùõøsubscriptùëùùêªùõøsubscriptùëùùê∂ketùëíquantum-operator-productùëí1ùëùùõøsubscriptùëùùêªùõøsubscriptùëùùê∂ùëîbraùëî\rho_{fin}=(p+\delta p_{H}+\delta p_{C})|e\rangle\langle e|+(1-p-\delta p_{H}-\delta p_{C})|g\rangle\langle g|. Heat is transfered between the qubit and the environment, with no work performed.

One of the novelties in the quantum regime is that the processes are now probabilistic, i.e., while we expect in the classical case that heat flows from the hot bath to the system for every single cycle at stage (ii), namely, Œ¥‚ÄãpH>0ùõøsubscriptùëùùêª0\delta p_{H}>0, there is in the quantum case a finite probability, for individual cycles, of the opposite to occur, namely, Œ¥‚ÄãpH<0ùõøsubscriptùëùùêª0\delta p_{H}<0. Thus, it is possible to observe a violation of the behavior expected by the second law of thermodynamics for individual quantum cycles. Naturally, conciliation with the second law is recovered on average over a long sequence of cycles¬†Kieu04 . Claims of violation of the second law have been considered, but they all typically use non-thermal baths (see, e.g., Ref.¬†Niedenzu17 ). Note also that the random violation of the second law for individual quantum cycles are due to quantum fluctuations rather than to thermal fluctuations.

The probabilistic character of a quantum engine implies that we need to enforce the cyclicity of the engine through the constraint that Œ¥‚ÄãpH+Œ¥‚ÄãpC=0ùõøsubscriptùëùùêªùõøsubscriptùëùùê∂0\delta p_{H}+\delta p_{C}=0, which ensures that the state of the system at the end of stage (iv) is equal to the initial state at the beginning of stage (i). By imposing such a constraint, we obtain that the total amount of work performed by the heat engine is

It then follows that the condition for positive work is, on average, TH>(œâ2/œâ1)‚ÄãTCsubscriptùëáùêªsubscriptùúî2subscriptùúî1subscriptùëáùê∂T_{H}>(\omega_{2}/\omega_{1})T_{C}. This is stronger than the classical condition of TH>TCsubscriptùëáùêªsubscriptùëáùê∂T_{H}>T_{C}. It can be understood by the fact that the system is expected to receive heat from the hot bath if TH>œâ2subscriptùëáùêªsubscriptùúî2T_{H}>\omega_{2} and to transfer heat to the cold bath if TC<œâ1subscriptùëáùê∂subscriptùúî1T_{C}<\omega_{1}.

3 Quantum Otto engine via Unruh effect

We now present the Unruh quantum Otto engine. In this case, the thermal bath comes from the thermal properties of the vacuum fluctuations given by the Unruh effect. Thus, the thermal reservoir has now a relativistic quantum origin, which is associated with the vacuum fluctuations of a quantum field. This implies that the Unruh effect is able to yield useful work in a cyclic process. As a working substance, we take a single qubit, which is designed to transform heat extracted from the vacuum into work. The stages proposed to the Unruh thermodynamic cycle are illustrated in Fig.¬†(1).

3.1 Kinematic cycle of the qubit

Since the observation of the Unruh effect depends on the state of motion of the qubit as it interacs with the quantum vacuum, a description of the kinematics of the qubit on the whole cycle is required. In this way, in addition to a thermodynamic closed cycle, we also assume a kinematic closed trajectory for the qubit traveling in spacetime. This will impose further constraints in the interaction time with the quantum vacuum, as it will be shown below. Thus, in the first and third step of the cycle, we assume the qubit keeps constant speed , while in the second and fourth steps, it moves with constant acceleration. This is explicitly shown in Fig.¬†(2). Notice that, while traveling at constant acceleration the qubit is brought into contact with the vacuum fluctuations. On the other hand, while at constant velocity and going through an adiabatic expansion/contraction of the energy gap, there is no contact between the qubit and the quantum field.

In order to assure that there is no change in the state of the system, caused by the vacuum, during the adiabatic processes of the cycle, we should keep the qubit decoupled of the vacuum at these steps. We are thus assuming that one can control the contact between the system and the vacuum in the very same way that one can control the coupling or decoupling between a system and a thermal reservoir in a classical thermal machine. For simplicity we assume a one-dimensional motion of the qubit. Thus, our closed trajectory is composed by the following steps:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Step 1: Constant velocity vùë£v during a period of time ùíØùíØ{\cal T}.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Step 2: Constant acceleration Œ±Hsubscriptùõºùêª\alpha_{H} during a period ùíØ2subscriptùíØ2{\cal T}_{2}. At this step, the qubit accelerates from speed vùë£v to ‚àívùë£-v.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Step 3: Constant velocity ‚àívùë£-v during a period of time ùíØùíØ{\cal T}.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Step 4: Constant acceleration Œ±Csubscriptùõºùê∂\alpha_{C} during a period ùíØ1subscriptùíØ1{\cal T}_{1}. At this step the qubit accelerates from speed ‚àívùë£-v to vùë£v.

It is worth noticing that times ùíØ1subscriptùíØ1{\cal T}_{1} and ùíØ2subscriptùíØ2{\cal T}_{2} are fixed by the values of vùë£v and Œ±H,Csubscriptùõºùêªùê∂\alpha_{H,C}. More specifically, we will shown that there is a relation between Œ±Hsubscriptùõºùêª\alpha_{H} and Œ±Csubscriptùõºùê∂\alpha_{C} in order to ensure that the system returns to its original state after one cycle. For now, we say that it is expected the accelerations (temperatures) satisfy Œ±H>Œ±Csubscriptùõºùêªsubscriptùõºùê∂\alpha_{H}>\alpha_{C} to ensure that at step 2 the vacuum behaves like a hot reservoir while at step 4 it acts like a cold reservoir.

The non-trivial motion of the qubit occurs when it is in contact with the vacuum. Indeed, in order for the vacuum to behave as a thermal bath, we have to ensure a motion with constant proper acceleration for the qubit¬†birrell . Therefore, during the stages of contact with the vacuum, we suppose that the qubit moves with constant proper acceleration, as described by the step 2 and step 4 of the kinematics cycle. This would ensure the thermal behavior of quantum vacuum as predicted by the Unruh effect. In general, if one considers a relativistic motion with constant proper acceleration Œ±ùõº\alpha, one finds that the spacetime coordinates of the particle are given by œá‚Äã(œÑ)=(t,x)ùúíùúèùë°ùë•\chi(\tau)=(t,x) where

xùë•\displaystyle x =\displaystyle= 1Œ±‚Äãcosh‚Å°(Œ±‚ÄãœÑ),1ùõºùõºùúè\displaystyle\frac{1}{\alpha}\cosh(\alpha\tau), (5)

being œÑùúè\tau the particle proper time. This hyperbolic spacetime trajectory of the qubit with constant acceleration is shown in Fig.¬†(3). From Eqs.¬†(5), the velocity of the qubit is given by

Then, we see then that if the qubit velocity begins at ‚àívùë£-v at time ‚àíœÑùúè-\tau, it will have velocity vùë£v at time œÑùúè\tau, where

œÑ=1Œ±‚Äãarctanh‚Å°(v).ùúè1ùõºarctanhùë£\tau=\frac{1}{\alpha}\operatorname{arctanh}(v). (7)

Then, the time that it takes for the qubit to change from velocity ‚àívùë£-v to vùë£v using a constant acceleration Œ±ùõº\alpha is 2‚ÄãœÑ=2‚Äãarctanh‚Å°(v)/Œ±2ùúè2arctanhùë£ùõº2\tau=2\operatorname{arctanh}(v)/\alpha. Hence, we have that, when the qubit has acceleration Œ±Hsubscriptùõºùêª\alpha_{H}, the interaction time with the vacuum is ùíØ2=2‚Äãarctanh‚Å°(v)/Œ±HsubscriptùíØ22arctanhùë£subscriptùõºùêª{\cal T}_{2}=2\operatorname{arctanh}(v)/\alpha_{H}, whereas when the qubit has acceleration Œ±Csubscriptùõºùê∂\alpha_{C} the interaction time with the vacuum is ùíØ1=2‚Äãarctanh‚Å°(v)/Œ±CsubscriptùíØ12arctanhùë£subscriptùõºùê∂{\cal T}_{1}=2\operatorname{arctanh}(v)/\alpha_{C}.

3.2 Adiabatic expansion of the energy gap

Now we describe the first stage of our engine. This process corresponds to an adiabatic expansion of the energy gap, where we assume that the energy gap of the qubit increases smoothly in time. Recalling that the qubit Hamiltonian is given by ‚Ñã=œâ‚Äã(t)‚Äã|e‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®e|‚Ñãùúîùë°ketùëíbraùëí{\cal H}=\omega(t)|e\rangle\langle e| and that we consider as the initial state of the qubit the density operator œÅi‚Äãn=p‚Äã|e‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®e|+(1‚àíp)|g‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®g|subscriptùúåùëñùëõùëùketùëíquantum-operator-productùëí1ùëùùëîbraùëî\rho_{in}=p|e\rangle\langle e|+(1-p)|g\rangle\langle g|, it follows that the state of the qubit all along this adiabatic process is kept constant, so œÅ‚Äã(t)=œÅi‚Äãnùúåùë°subscriptùúåùëñùëõ\rho(t)=\rho_{in}. Therefore, we obtain that during the adiabatic expansion there is no heat absorbed by the qubit, i.e.

‚ü®Q1‚ü©=‚à´0ùíØùëët‚ÄãTr‚Äã(d‚ÄãœÅ‚Äã(t)d‚Äãt‚Äã‚Ñã‚Äã(t))=0.delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëÑ1superscriptsubscript0ùíØdifferential-dùë°Trùëëùúåùë°ùëëùë°‚Ñãùë°0\langle Q_{1}\rangle=\int_{0}^{\cal T}dt\,\,\text{Tr}\left(\frac{d\rho(t)}{dt}{\cal H}(t)\right)=0. (8)

However the energy gap expansion of the qubit comes at the cost of work on it, which reads

‚ü®W1‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëä1\displaystyle\langle W_{1}\rangle =\displaystyle= ‚à´0ùíØùëët‚ÄãTr‚Äã(œÅ‚Äã(t)‚Äãd‚Äã‚Ñã‚Äã(t)d‚Äãt),superscriptsubscript0ùíØdifferential-dùë°Trùúåùë°ùëë‚Ñãùë°ùëëùë°\displaystyle\int_{0}^{\cal T}dt\,\,\text{Tr}\left(\rho(t)\frac{d{\cal H}(t)}{dt}\right), (9)
=\displaystyle= ‚à´0ùíØùëët‚ÄãTr‚Äã(œÅi‚Äãn‚Äãd‚Äã(œâ‚Äã(t)‚Äã|e‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®e|)d‚Äãt),superscriptsubscript0ùíØdifferential-dùë°Trsubscriptùúåùëñùëõùëëùúîùë°ketùëíbraùëíùëëùë°\displaystyle\int_{0}^{\cal T}dt\,\,\text{Tr}\left(\rho_{in}\frac{d(\omega(t)|e\rangle\langle e|)}{dt}\right),
=\displaystyle= ‚à´0ùíØùëët‚Äãd‚Äãœâ‚Äã(t)d‚Äãt‚ÄãTr‚Äã(œÅi‚Äãn‚Äã|e‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®e|).superscriptsubscript0ùíØdifferential-dùë°ùëëùúîùë°ùëëùë°Trsubscriptùúåùëñùëõketùëíbraùëí\displaystyle\int_{0}^{\cal T}dt\,\,\frac{d\omega(t)}{dt}\,\,\text{Tr}\left(\rho_{in}|e\rangle\langle e|\right).

We now use that Tr‚Äã(œÅi‚Äãn‚Äã|e‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®e|)=pTrsubscriptùúåùëñùëõketùëíbraùëíùëù\text{Tr}\left(\rho_{in}|e\rangle\langle e|\right)=p, where pùëùp is the probability of finding the system in the excited state |e‚ü©ketùëí|e\rangle. Moreover, considering that the excited state increases its energy level in the adiabatic expansion from œâ‚Äã(t=0)=œâ1ùúîùë°0subscriptùúî1\omega(t=0)=\omega_{1} to œâ‚Äã(t=ùíØ)=œâ2ùúîùë°ùíØsubscriptùúî2\omega(t={\cal T})=\omega_{2}, we get a positive work given by

‚ü®W1‚ü©=p‚Äã(œâ2‚àíœâ1).delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëä1ùëùsubscriptùúî2subscriptùúî1\langle W_{1}\rangle=p\,\left(\omega_{2}-\omega_{1}\right). (10)

3.3 Contact with the hot quantum vacuum

In this part of the cycle we take advantage of the Unruh effect to simulate a thermal bath to the qubit. We take the qubit as interacting with a quantum massless scalar field in its ground state of zero particles, i.e. in its vacuum state |0‚ü©ket0|0\rangle. Due to the Unruh effect we know that this quantum vacuum would behaved like a thermal bath with respect to the qubit when it moves in an accelerated trajectory. Therefore the kinematics description of the qubit previously presented is crucial for this part of the cycle. An important remark here is that we suppose that the qubit system is small enough so that it does not affect the state of the scalar field and disturb the quantum vacuum state.

During the interaction of the qubit with the quantum scalar field, we consider that the Hamiltonian of the total qubit-field system is given by

‚Ñç=‚Ñç0+‚Ñçi‚Äãn‚Äãt,‚Ñçsubscript‚Ñç0subscript‚Ñçùëñùëõùë°\mathbb{H}=\mathbb{H}_{0}+\mathbb{H}_{int}, (11)

where ‚Ñç0subscript‚Ñç0\mathbb{H}_{0} is the free Hamiltonian and ‚Ñçi‚Äãn‚Äãtsubscript‚Ñçùëñùëõùë°\mathbb{H}_{int} is the qubit-field interaction Hamiltonian. The Hamiltonian ‚Ñç0subscript‚Ñç0\mathbb{H}_{0} reads

‚Ñç0=‚Ñã+‚Ñãf‚Äãi‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äãd,subscript‚Ñç0‚Ñãsuperscript‚Ñãùëìùëñùëíùëôùëë\mathbb{H}_{0}={\cal H}+{\cal H}^{field}, (12)

where ‚Ñã‚Ñã{\cal H} denotes the qubit free Hamiltonian ‚Ñã=œâ2‚Äã|e‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®e|‚Ñãsubscriptùúî2ketùëíbraùëí{\cal H}=\omega_{2}|e\rangle\langle e|, with œâ2subscriptùúî2\omega_{2} the constant gap along this stage, and ‚Ñãf‚Äãi‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äãd=‚à´d3‚Äãx‚Äã(1/2)‚Äã{(‚àÇtœÜ)2+(‚àáœÜ)2}superscript‚Ñãùëìùëñùëíùëôùëësuperscriptùëë3ùë•12superscriptsubscriptùë°ùúë2superscript‚àáùúë2{\cal H}^{field}=\int d^{3}x(1/2)\{(\partial_{t}\varphi)^{2}+(\nabla\varphi)^{2}\} is the Klein-Gordon Hamiltonian associated to a free massless scalar field œÜùúë\varphi. The qubit-field interaction Hamiltonian is given by the linear coupling dewitt1979

‚Ñçi‚Äãn‚Äãt=g‚Äãm‚ÄãœÜ‚Äã(œá‚Äã(œÑ)),subscript‚Ñçùëñùëõùë°ùëîùëöùúëùúíùúè\mathbb{H}_{int}=g\,m\varphi(\chi(\tau)), (13)

where gùëîg is the coupling constant of the interaction, mùëöm is the qubit monopole operator, which is given by

m=|e‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®g|+|g‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®e|,ùëöketùëíbraùëîketùëîbraùëím=|e\rangle\langle g|+|g\rangle\langle e|, (14)

and the scalar field œÜ‚Äã(œá‚Äã(œÑ))ùúëùúíùúè\varphi(\chi(\tau)) is evaluated on the spacetime point œá‚Äã(œÑ)=(t,x)ùúíùúèùë°ùë•\chi(\tau)=(t,x) where the qubit is located. We suppose at this stage that the qubit has a constant acceleration Œ±Hsubscriptùõºùêª\alpha_{H}, with a spacetime trajectory analog to that given in Eq. (5).

We consider that the scalar field start its evolution at the vacuum state and the initial state of the qubit-field is the tensor product œ±i‚Äãn=œÅi‚Äãn‚äó|0‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®0|subscriptitalic-œ±ùëñùëõtensor-productsubscriptùúåùëñùëõket0bra0\varrho_{in}=\rho_{in}\otimes|0\rangle\langle 0|. We adopt here the interaction picture, where we apply a perturbative approach and a Dyson series to obtain the final state of the qubit up to second order in the small coupling constant gùëîg. This is shown in details in Appendix A. We then show that the final state of the qubit after interacting with the vacuum is

œÅ‚Äã(t)=œÅi‚Äãn+Œ¥‚ÄãpH‚Äã(t)‚ÄãœÉ3,ùúåùë°subscriptùúåùëñùëõùõøsubscriptùëùùêªùë°subscriptùúé3\rho(t)=\rho_{in}+\delta p_{H}(t)\sigma_{3}, (15)

where œÉ3=(|e‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®e|‚àí|g‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®g|)subscriptùúé3ketùëíbraùëíketùëîbraùëî\sigma_{3}=(|e\rangle\langle e|-|g\rangle\langle g|) is the third Pauli matrix and the time tùë°t during this vacuum contact is restricted to ‚àíœÑ2<t<œÑ2subscriptùúè2ùë°subscriptùúè2-\tau_{2}<t<\tau_{2}, with œÑ2=arctanh‚Å°(v)/Œ±Hsubscriptùúè2arctanhùë£subscriptùõºùêª\tau_{2}=\operatorname{arctanh}(v)/\alpha_{H}. The change in the population of the excited state is given by

Œ¥‚ÄãpH‚Äã(t)=g2‚Äã‚à´‚àíœÑ2tùëëœÑ‚Äã‚à´‚àíœÑ2tùëëœÑ‚Ä≤‚Äã((1‚àíp)‚Äãe‚àíi‚Äãœâ2‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãœÑ‚àíp‚Äãei‚Äãœâ2‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãœÑ)‚ÄãGŒ±H+‚Äã(œÑ,œÑ‚Ä≤),ùõøsubscriptùëùùêªùë°superscriptùëî2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùúè2ùë°differential-dùúèsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùúè2ùë°differential-dsuperscriptùúè‚Ä≤1ùëùsuperscriptùëíùëñsubscriptùúî2Œîùúèùëùsuperscriptùëíùëñsubscriptùúî2Œîùúèsubscriptsuperscriptùê∫subscriptùõºùêªùúèsuperscriptùúè‚Ä≤\delta p_{H}(t)=g^{2}\int_{-\tau_{2}}^{t}d\tau\int_{-\tau_{2}}^{t}d\tau^{\prime}\left((1-p)e^{-i\omega_{2}\Delta\tau}-p\,e^{i\omega_{2}\Delta\tau}\right)G^{+}_{\alpha_{H}}(\tau,\tau^{\prime}), (16)

This vacuum correlation function evaluated on the accelerated trajectory of the qubit captures the thermal nature of the vacuum fluctuations. Therefore, at some time tùë°t during the interaction with the quantum vacuum the density operator of the qubit is given by

œÅ‚Äã(t)=(p+Œ¥‚ÄãpH‚Äã(t)001‚àí(p+Œ¥‚ÄãpH‚Äã(t))).ùúåùë°ùëùùõøsubscriptùëùùêªùë°001ùëùùõøsubscriptùëùùêªùë°\rho(t)=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}p+\delta p_{H}(t)&0\\ 0&1-(p+\delta p_{H}(t))\end{array}\right). (17)

One can see that the increase of the population of the excited state, Eq. (16), is caused by the interaction with the vacuum and this would give us a thermal like response, as predicted by the Unruh effect. We also observe that the change in the probability of finding the qubit in its excited state depends on the initial population of this state pùëùp, on the energy gap œâ2subscriptùúî2\omega_{2} and on the acceleration Œ±Hsubscriptùõºùêª\alpha_{H}, which plays the role of hot temperature in the Unruh quantum machine.

We can then evaluate the average heat and work over the qubit during the contact with the hot quantum vacuum. From the state of the qubit given by Eq. ‚ü®Q2‚ü©=‚à´‚àíœÑ2œÑ2ùëët‚ÄãTr‚Äã(d‚ÄãœÅ‚Äã(t)d‚Äãt‚Äã‚Ñã‚Äã(t)).delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëÑ2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùúè2subscriptùúè2differential-dùë°Trùëëùúåùë°ùëëùë°‚Ñãùë°\langle Q_{2}\rangle=\int_{-\tau_{2}}^{\tau_{2}}dt\,\,\text{Tr}\left(\frac{d\rho(t)}{dt}{\cal H}(t)\right). We will discuss ahead the conditions to ensure that Œ¥‚ÄãpHùõøsubscriptùëùùêª\delta p_{H} and the heat absorbed from the vacuum ‚ü®Q2‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëÑ2\langle Q_{2}\rangle are both positive, so the quantum vacuum here really behaves as a hot reservoir. As at this stage of the cycle, the qubit Hamiltonian is constant ‚Ñã=œâ2‚Äã|e‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®e|‚Ñãsubscriptùúî2ketùëíbraùëí{\cal H}=\omega_{2}|e\rangle\langle e|, which implies that we get no work, i.e.

‚ü®W2‚ü©=‚à´‚àíœÑ2œÑ2ùëët‚ÄãTr‚Äã(œÅ‚Äã(t)‚Äãd‚Äã‚Ñãd‚Äãt)=0.delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëä2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùúè2subscriptùúè2differential-dùë°Trùúåùë°ùëë‚Ñãùëëùë°0\langle W_{2}\rangle=\int_{-\tau_{2}}^{\tau_{2}}dt\,\,\text{Tr}\left(\rho(t)\frac{d{\cal H}}{dt}\right)=0. (21)

3.4 Adiabatic contraction of the energy gap

We suppose next that the energy gap is contracted by means of external fields. The specific way this contraction occurs is not important, but in order to ensure a closed cycle for the quantum heat engine, we have to get back to the initial energy gap. Then, at this stage we decouple the qubit from the vacuum. Hence, the system is kept in the state

œÅ=(p+Œ¥‚ÄãpH001‚àí(p+Œ¥‚ÄãpH)).ùúåùëùùõøsubscriptùëùùêª001ùëùùõøsubscriptùëùùêª\rho=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}p+\delta p_{H}&0\\ 0&1-(p+\delta p_{H})\end{array}\right). (22)

Again, the change in the energy levels of the qubit Hamiltonian does not affect the state of the qubit. Then, the state of the qubit remains fixed as in Eq. (22) all over the adiabatic contraction and there is no heat transfer. On the other hand, the qubit realizes work, which is proportional to the energy gap change and to the population of the excited state. In this way we straightforwardly obtain that, during the adiabatic contraction, heat and work read

‚ü®Q3‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëÑ3\displaystyle\langle Q_{3}\rangle =\displaystyle= 0,0\displaystyle 0,
‚ü®W3‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëä3\displaystyle\langle W_{3}\rangle =\displaystyle= (p+Œ¥‚ÄãpH)‚Äã(œâ1‚àíœâ2),ùëùùõøsubscriptùëùùêªsubscriptùúî1subscriptùúî2\displaystyle(p+\delta p_{H})(\omega_{1}-\omega_{2}), (23)

where the energy gap contraction is taken from œâ2subscriptùúî2\omega_{2} to the initial lower value œâ1subscriptùúî1\omega_{1} considered at stage 1 of the quantum cycle.

3.5 Contact with the cold quantum vacuum

Here we consider that the qubit is bring into contact with the quantum vacuum again, but now with acceleration Œ±C<Œ±Hsubscriptùõºùê∂subscriptùõºùêª\alpha_{C}<\alpha_{H}. So, at this stage, the vacuum plays the role of a the cold bath reservoir. The qubit has a lower energy gap œâ1subscriptùúî1\omega_{1} in this process and its initial state is

œÅ=(p‚Ä≤001‚àíp‚Ä≤),ùúåsuperscriptùëù‚Ä≤001superscriptùëù‚Ä≤\rho=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}p^{\prime}&0\\ 0&1-p^{\prime}\end{array}\right), (24)

where we have defined p‚Ä≤=p+Œ¥‚ÄãpHsuperscriptùëù‚Ä≤ùëùùõøsubscriptùëùùêªp^{\prime}=p+\delta p_{H}. Then we have that the final state of the qubit is given by

œÅf‚Äãi‚Äãn=(p‚Ä≤+Œ¥‚ÄãpC001‚àí(p‚Ä≤+Œ¥‚ÄãpC)),subscriptùúåùëìùëñùëõsuperscriptùëù‚Ä≤ùõøsubscriptùëùùê∂001superscriptùëù‚Ä≤ùõøsubscriptùëùùê∂\rho_{fin}=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}p^{\prime}+\delta p_{C}&0\\ 0&1-(p^{\prime}+\delta p_{C})\end{array}\right), (25)

where the new change in the probability of the excited state is given by

Œ¥‚ÄãpC=g2‚Äã‚à´‚àíœÑ1œÑ1ùëëœÑ‚Äã‚à´‚àíœÑ1œÑ1ùëëœÑ‚Ä≤‚Äã((1‚àíp‚Ä≤)‚Äãe‚àíi‚Äãœâ1‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãœÑ‚àíp‚Ä≤‚Äãei‚Äãœâ1‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãœÑ)‚ÄãGŒ±C+‚Äã(œÑ,œÑ‚Ä≤),ùõøsubscriptùëùùê∂superscriptùëî2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùúè1subscriptùúè1differential-dùúèsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùúè1subscriptùúè1differential-dsuperscriptùúè‚Ä≤1superscriptùëù‚Ä≤superscriptùëíùëñsubscriptùúî1Œîùúèsuperscriptùëù‚Ä≤superscriptùëíùëñsubscriptùúî1Œîùúèsubscriptsuperscriptùê∫subscriptùõºùê∂ùúèsuperscriptùúè‚Ä≤\delta p_{C}=g^{2}\int_{-\tau_{1}}^{\tau_{1}}d\tau\int_{-\tau_{1}}^{\tau_{1}}d\tau^{\prime}\left((1-p^{\prime})e^{-i\omega_{1}\Delta\tau}-p^{\prime}\,e^{i\omega_{1}\Delta\tau}\right)G^{+}_{\alpha_{C}}(\tau,\tau^{\prime}), (26)

as discussed in Appendix¬† A. By considering only terms up to second order in the coupling constant and realizing that the first correction Œ¥‚ÄãpHùõøsubscriptùëùùêª\delta p_{H} of Eq. (20) is already of order two, we can show that

Œ¥‚ÄãpC=g2‚Äã‚à´‚àíœÑ1œÑ1ùëëœÑ‚Äã‚à´‚àíœÑ1œÑ1ùëëœÑ‚Ä≤‚Äã((1‚àíp)‚Äãe‚àíi‚Äãœâ1‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãœÑ‚àíp‚Äãei‚Äãœâ1‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãœÑ)‚ÄãGŒ±C+‚Äã(œÑ,œÑ‚Ä≤).ùõøsubscriptùëùùê∂superscriptùëî2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùúè1subscriptùúè1differential-dùúèsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùúè1subscriptùúè1differential-dsuperscriptùúè‚Ä≤1ùëùsuperscriptùëíùëñsubscriptùúî1Œîùúèùëùsuperscriptùëíùëñsubscriptùúî1Œîùúèsubscriptsuperscriptùê∫subscriptùõºùê∂ùúèsuperscriptùúè‚Ä≤\delta p_{C}=g^{2}\int_{-\tau_{1}}^{\tau_{1}}d\tau\int_{-\tau_{1}}^{\tau_{1}}d\tau^{\prime}\left((1-p)e^{-i\omega_{1}\Delta\tau}-p\,e^{i\omega_{1}\Delta\tau}\right)G^{+}_{\alpha_{C}}(\tau,\tau^{\prime}). (27)

Note that here we have considered that the energy gap of the qubit is œâ1subscriptùúî1\omega_{1} and that the acceleration in this stage of the cycle is lower that previously Œ±C<Œ±Hsubscriptùõºùê∂subscriptùõºùêª\alpha_{C}<\alpha_{H}. This expression is very similar to that one we have obtained for the case of a hot quantum vacuum. However, in the same way that we must ensure that, during the first contact of the qubit with the quantum vacuum, it absorbed heat, i.e. Œ¥‚ÄãpH>0ùõøsubscriptùëùùêª0\delta p_{H}>0, here we must require that, in order for the vacuum to behave as a cold reservoir, the qubit have to transfer heat to the vacuum, i.e., Œ¥‚ÄãpC<0ùõøsubscriptùëùùê∂0\delta p_{C}<0. As we will see, these conditions are not independent of each other, since we also need to ensure that during a cycle the qubit comes back to its original state. As before, we can obtain the average quantum heat and the work produced in this part of the cycle, which read

‚ü®Q4‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëÑ4\displaystyle\langle Q_{4}\rangle =\displaystyle= œâ1‚ÄãŒ¥‚ÄãpC,subscriptùúî1ùõøsubscriptùëùùê∂\displaystyle\omega_{1}\delta p_{C},
‚ü®W4‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëä4\displaystyle\langle W_{4}\rangle =\displaystyle= 0.0\displaystyle 0. (28)

After this stage of the cycle, we must impose that the system comes back to its initial state. Then the final state of the qubit, given by Eq. (25), requires Œ¥‚ÄãpC+Œ¥‚ÄãpH=0ùõøsubscriptùëùùê∂ùõøsubscriptùëùùêª0\delta p_{C}+\delta p_{H}=0. This cyclicity condition, together with the efficiency of the cycle, are analyzed in the next sections.

4 Quantum vacuum fluctuations effects

From our previous results, we have found that the corrections induced by the vacuum fluctuations to the qubit excited state population can be written in a general form as

Œ¥‚Äãp=g2‚Äã‚à´‚àíœÑœÑùëët‚Äã‚à´‚àíœÑœÑùëët‚Ä≤‚Äã((1‚àíp)‚Äãe‚àíi‚Äãœâ‚ÄãŒî‚Äãt‚àíp‚Äãei‚Äãœâ‚ÄãŒî‚Äãt)‚ÄãGŒ±+‚Äã(t,t‚Ä≤),ùõøùëùsuperscriptùëî2superscriptsubscriptùúèùúèdifferential-dùë°superscriptsubscriptùúèùúèdifferential-dsuperscriptùë°‚Ä≤1ùëùsuperscriptùëíùëñùúîŒîùë°ùëùsuperscriptùëíùëñùúîŒîùë°subscriptsuperscriptùê∫ùõºùë°superscriptùë°‚Ä≤\delta p=g^{2}\int_{-\tau}^{\tau}dt\int_{-\tau}^{\tau}dt^{\prime}\left((1-p)e^{-i\omega\Delta t}-p\,e^{i\omega\Delta t}\right)G^{+}_{\alpha}(t,t^{\prime}), (29)

where Œ±ùõº\alpha is the qubit acceleration, œâùúî\omega is the qubit energy gap, pùëùp is the initial population of the excited state, and 2‚ÄãœÑ2ùúè2\tau is the interaction time of the qubit with the vacuum. However, as we need to ensure a kinematically closed cycle for the qubit, we require that the interaction time of the qubit with the vacuum is such that

œÑ=arctanh‚Å°(v)/Œ±.ùúèarctanhùë£ùõº\tau=\operatorname{arctanh}(v)/\alpha. (30)

On the other hand, as it is shown in Appendix¬† B, the qubit acceleration and the qubit energy gap appear as a single variable, which motivates the definition of the ratio a‚â°Œ±/œâùëéùõºùúîa\equiv\alpha/\omega, here called as reduced acceleration. In turn, the correction to the excited state population Eq. (B.18), is then written as

Œ¥‚Äãp=Œ¥‚Äãp‚Äã(a,p,v)=g2‚Äã((1‚àí2‚Äãp)‚ÄãJ‚Äã(‚àí1a,2‚Äãarctanh‚Å°v)‚àíp‚Äãarctanh‚Å°v2‚Äãa).ùõøùëùùõøùëùùëéùëùùë£superscriptùëî212ùëùùêΩ1ùëé2arctanhùë£ùëùarctanhùë£2ùëé\delta p=\delta p(a,p,v)=g^{2}\left((1-2p)J\left(-\frac{1}{a},2\operatorname{arctanh}{v}\right)-p\frac{\operatorname{arctanh}{v}}{2a}\right). (31)

We will now numerically analyze the behavior of Œ¥‚Äãpùõøùëù\delta p given in Eq. (31) for different regimes of the Unruh machine. The behavior of Œ¥‚Äãpùõøùëù\delta p can be provided as a function of the reduced acceleration a=Œ±/œâùëéùõºùúîa=\alpha/\omega, for different values of initial probabilities pùëùp and velocities vùë£v. The results are illustrated in Fig. (4). Note that the corrections Œ¥‚Äãpùõøùëù\delta p always increase with the acceleration, which plays here the role of the quantum vacuum temperature. In particular, these corrections asymptotically tend to a velocity-dependent constant value for sufficiently high accelerations. Moreover, notice that perturbation theory requires that |Œ¥‚Äãp|‚â™pmuch-less-thanùõøùëùùëù|\delta p|\ll p. This condition may be violated for small aùëéa, which indicates a breakdown of the perturbative approach. Indeed, as given by Eq.¬†(30), the interaction time œÑùúè\tau tends to increase as we decrease aùëéa for a fixed velocity vùë£v. Since the integral in Eq.¬†(29) implies that |Œ¥‚Äãp|‚àùg2‚Äãœâ‚ÄãœÑ‚Äãpproportional-toùõøùëùsuperscriptùëî2ùúîùúèùëù|\delta p|\propto g^{2}\omega\tau p, we have that a large |Œ¥‚Äãp|ùõøùëù|\delta p| may be yielded in the region of small aùëéa. This regime is forbidden by perturbation theory and is roughly indicated by the hatched gray areas in Fig. (4). In fact, by imposing |Œ¥‚Äãp|‚â™pmuch-less-thanùõøùëùùëù|\delta p|\ll p, for p>0ùëù0p>0, we then obtain the condition g2‚Äãœâ‚ÄãœÑ‚â™1much-less-thansuperscriptùëî2ùúîùúè1g^{2}\omega\tau\ll 1, which leads to

a‚â´g2‚Äãarctanh‚Å°(v).much-greater-thanùëésuperscriptùëî2arctanhùë£a\gg g^{2}\operatorname{arctanh}(v). (32)

Let us discuss in more details the special cases for initial probabilities p=0ùëù0p=0, 0<p<1/20ùëù120<p<1/2 and 1/2<p<112ùëù11/2<p<1, which are exhibited in Figs. (4a, 4b, 4c), respectively. For the case p=0ùëù0p=0, we have that the excited state is initially empty and the qubit begins the interaction with the vacuum in its ground state. The breakdown of the perturbative approach appears here in the negative corrections Œ¥‚Äãpùõøùëù\delta p for small aùëéa and this is represented by the gray area. This area, between a=0ùëé0a=0 and a=20ùëé20a=20, encloses one order of magnitude greater that g2‚Äãarctanh‚Å°(v)superscriptùëî2arctanhùë£g^{2}\operatorname{arctanh}(v), for g=1ùëî1g=1 and v=0.99ùë£0.99v=0.99, as dictated by Eq. (32). For larger values of aùëéa, the correction Œ¥‚Äãpùõøùëù\delta p, gets positive and asymptotically increases for larger velocities vùë£v. This result is consistent with the Unruh effect since, if the system is prepared at the ground state, then the thermal fluctuations created by the Unruh effect would induce an increase in the excited state population. In addition, if vùë£v is increased, this means a longer interaction time œÑùúè\tau for a fixed acceleration aùëéa, which is expected to yield an asymptotically larger correction Œ¥‚Äãpùõøùëù\delta p.

For p=1/4ùëù14p=1/4, as shown in Fig. (4b), we again see for high accelerations an asymptotically constant value of Œ¥‚Äãpùõøùëù\delta p that increases as a function vùë£v, as expected by the Unruh effect. For small acceleration values, we also observe the breakdown of the perturbative approach through the crossings of the curves for distinct values of vùë£v. The crossings would mean that different interaction times œÑùúè\tau would imply the same excitation Œ¥‚Äãpùõøùëù\delta p, which is a clearly a limitation of the perturbation theory. Moreover, for the point of vanishing acceleration, a=0ùëé0a=0, we see that a negative divergence appears. The origin of this behavior can be traced back to the the integral in Eq. (29), which is proportional to the interaction time interval. Since œÑ‚àº1/asimilar-toùúè1ùëé\tau\sim 1/a, then a divergence comes out for small aùëéa. This occurs because we would need an infinite time interval to change the velocity from vùë£v to ‚àívùë£-v, by moving the qubit with zero acceleration.

The case p=3/4ùëù34p=3/4 is presented at Fig. (4c). We observe that, for this population of the excited state, the vacuum fluctuations would always cause a decrease of the original highly populated excited state. Then, spontaneous and stimulated decay in the qubit energy state would overcome the excitations caused by the Unruh effect. As the acceleration aùëéa becomes larger, we have that the corrections Œ¥‚Äãpùõøùëù\delta p increase, but keeping always negative as a function of aùëéa.

In Fig. (4d), we show the behavior of Œ¥‚Äãpùõøùëù\delta p as a function of aùëéa for different initial populations pùëùp of the excited state for a fixed velocity. This plot summarizes the previously discussed behaviors for both p<1/2ùëù12p<1/2 and p>1/2ùëù12p>1/2. For the special case p=1/2ùëù12p=1/2, any value of accelerations the Unruh thermal radiation produces a decay in the qubit energy state. However, in the limit of a‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëéa\rightarrow\infty, the corrections are vanishing, i.e. Œ¥‚Äãp=0ùõøùëù0\delta p=0. Then, in this case, high accelerations produce a balance on the original equally populated states and no net effect can be detected. In conclusion, it follows that, in order to gain heat from the quantum vacuum, we would require an initial state with 0‚â§p<1/20ùëù120\leq p<1/2. Moreover, perturbation theory requires (32) as a validation approach.

We now illustrate in Fig. (5) the behavior of Œ¥‚Äãpùõøùëù\delta p as a function of the initial population pùëùp of the excited state. As it can be seen, the correction Œ¥‚Äãpùõøùëù\delta p is linear with pùëùp, as expected from Eq. (31). In addition, this linear response is such that Œ¥‚Äãpùõøùëù\delta p decreases as the initial population pùëùp increases. This result is consistent with the Unruh effect over the qubit. For p‚âà0ùëù0p\approx 0, we have an initially lowly populated excited state, so that one expects that the Unruh effect yields an increase of its population, i.e. Œ¥‚Äãp>0ùõøùëù0\delta p>0. On the other hand, for p‚âà1ùëù1p\approx 1, the vacuum fluctuations are expected to yield a decay, i.e. Œ¥‚Äãp<0ùõøùëù0\delta p<0. Therefore, as pùëùp goes from 00 to 111, one expects the corrections Œ¥‚Äãpùõøùëù\delta p to decrease and invert its signal, as shown in Fig. (5).

In all the plots of Fig. (5), we also show a lighter gray area, which represents the allowed values for the corrections Œ¥‚Äãpùõøùëù\delta p in order to get final positive probabilities less than one. Then, this lighter gray area ensures 0<p+Œ¥‚Äãp<10ùëùùõøùëù10<p+\delta p<1, for illustration in this area it has been adopted g=1ùëî1g=1. In order to evidence the limits of the perturbative approach we see that there exist values of Œ¥‚Äãpùõøùëù\delta p that are not in the lighter gray area. However, by using a lower value of the coupling constant as, for example, g=0.1ùëî0.1g=0.1, we get that the lighter gray area expands, making better the perturbative results. Then, the lighter gray area is a necessary condition for the validity of perturbation theory. In Fig. (5) the darker gray area indicates a stronger constraint over perturbation theory, provided by Eq.¬†(32). This condition gives us the value of the maximum allowed velocity vm‚Äãa‚Äãxsubscriptùë£ùëöùëéùë•v_{max} given a value for the acceleration aùëéa. From Eq.¬†(32), we adopt vm‚Äãa‚Äãx=tanh‚Å°(a/g2)subscriptùë£ùëöùëéùë•ùëésuperscriptùëî2v_{max}=\tanh(a/g^{2}). In Fig. (5a), we have analyzed the case for a small reduced acceleration. In this case, we find that only very small values of the velocity remain in the domain of validity. As we increase acceleration, Fig. (5b), we note that perturbation theory remains valid for a wider range of velocities and only very high velocities v‚àº1similar-toùë£1v\sim 1 are capable to break down the perturbative results. The cases of high and ultrahigh accelerations, shown in Figs. (5c) and (5d), respectively, are rather robust against violations of the perturbative regime.

5 Efficiency and cyclicity of the Unruh heat engine

We can summarize the Unruh heat engine cycle as shown in Fig. (6). There, we explicitly exhibit the absorbed heat and produced work at each part of the cycle, as well as the changes in the qubit density operator. As we mentioned before, the first contact of the qubit with the quantum vacuum occurs as it moves at a high acceleration Œ±Hsubscriptùõºùêª\alpha_{H}. In this part of the cycle the qubit should absorb heat ‚ü®Q2‚ü©>0delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëÑ20\langle Q_{2}\rangle>0 from the quantum vacuum and increase the population of the excited state by Œ¥‚ÄãpH>0ùõøsubscriptùëùùêª0\delta p_{H}>0. After this first contact, the qubit undergoes a contraction of the energy gap. Then, it is put in contact with the quantum vacuum again. During the second contact of the qubit with the quantum vacuum, it should transfer heat ‚ü®Q4‚ü©<0delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëÑ40\langle Q_{4}\rangle<0 and changes its excited state population by Œ¥‚ÄãpC<0ùõøsubscriptùëùùê∂0\delta p_{C}<0. Therefore, in order for the cycle to yield positive net work, we need to assure both that the vacuum behaves like the hot thermal reservoir in the first contact with the qubit and that it acts as a cold thermal reservoir in the second contact with the qubit. We can explicitly analyze the regimes for these conditions to be obeyed. As we previously mentioned, to obtain a closed cycle, we require that the qubit comes back to its original state as the machine returns to its first stage, which means

Œ¥‚ÄãpH+Œ¥‚ÄãpC=0.ùõøsubscriptùëùùêªùõøsubscriptùëùùê∂0\delta p_{H}+\delta p_{C}=0. (33)

Since we expect that Œ¥‚ÄãpH>0ùõøsubscriptùëùùêª0\delta p_{H}>0, then we should also have Œ¥‚ÄãpC<0ùõøsubscriptùëùùê∂0\delta p_{C}<0. The periodic condition given by Eq. (33) is equivalent to require that the first law of thermodynamics remains valid on average for our process, as we will see. Consequently, this leads us to the total mean quantum heat absorbed by the qubit from the vacuum

‚ü®Q‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëÑ\displaystyle\langle Q\rangle =\displaystyle= ‚ü®Q2‚ü©+‚ü®Q4‚ü©,delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëÑ2delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëÑ4\displaystyle\langle Q_{2}\rangle+\langle Q_{4}\rangle, (34)
=\displaystyle= œâ2‚ÄãŒ¥‚ÄãpH+œâ1‚ÄãŒ¥‚ÄãpC,subscriptùúî2ùõøsubscriptùëùùêªsubscriptùúî1ùõøsubscriptùëùùê∂\displaystyle\omega_{2}\delta p_{H}+\omega_{1}\delta p_{C},
=\displaystyle= (œâ2‚àíœâ1)‚ÄãŒ¥‚ÄãpH.subscriptùúî2subscriptùúî1ùõøsubscriptùëùùêª\displaystyle(\omega_{2}-\omega_{1})\delta p_{H}.

On the other hand, work is realized only during the adiabatic expansion or contraction of its energy gap. Hence, the total work produced over the qubit is

‚ü®W‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëä\displaystyle\langle W\rangle =\displaystyle= ‚ü®W1‚ü©+‚ü®W3‚ü©,delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëä1delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëä3\displaystyle\langle W_{1}\rangle+\langle W_{3}\rangle, (35)
=\displaystyle= (œâ2‚àíœâ1)‚Äãp+(œâ1‚àíœâ2)‚Äã(p+Œ¥‚ÄãpH),subscriptùúî2subscriptùúî1ùëùsubscriptùúî1subscriptùúî2ùëùùõøsubscriptùëùùêª\displaystyle(\omega_{2}-\omega_{1})p+(\omega_{1}-\omega_{2})(p+\delta p_{H}),
=\displaystyle= (œâ1‚àíœâ2)‚ÄãŒ¥‚ÄãpH.subscriptùúî1subscriptùúî2ùõøsubscriptùëùùêª\displaystyle(\omega_{1}-\omega_{2})\delta p_{H}.

Then, as one can see, the net work produced over the qubit and the total heat absorbed from the vacuum satisfies ‚ü®Q‚ü©+‚ü®W‚ü©=0delimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëÑdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëä0\langle Q\rangle+\langle W\rangle=0, as is expected from the first law of thermodynamics. Since ‚ü®W‚ü©delimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëä\langle W\rangle is the work performed over the qubit by external forces, then the work performed by the qubit over the exterior is given by ‚ü®W‚ü©e‚Äãx‚Äãt=‚àí‚ü®W‚ü©subscriptdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëäùëíùë•ùë°delimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëä\langle W\rangle_{ext}=-\langle W\rangle. Hence, we define the efficiency Œ∑ùúÇ\eta as

Œ∑=‚ü®W‚ü©e‚Äãx‚Äãt‚ü®Q2‚ü©,ùúÇsubscriptdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëäùëíùë•ùë°delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëÑ2\eta=\frac{\langle W\rangle_{ext}}{\langle Q_{2}\rangle}, (36)

which yields

Œ∑=1‚àíœâ1œâ2.ùúÇ1subscriptùúî1subscriptùúî2\eta=1-\frac{\omega_{1}}{\omega_{2}}. (37)

The efficiency depends only on the ratio of the minimum and maximum energy gaps and is independent of the accelerations (temperatures) we have considered. Moreover, this is the same efficiency found by using a classical thermal bath¬†Kieu04 , which suggestes a kind of universal bound independently of the nature of the thermal reservoir.

Let us now, proceed to analyze the kinematic constraints for the cyclic condition of the qubit state, Eq. (33). By defining the hot aHsubscriptùëéùêªa_{H} and cold aCsubscriptùëéùê∂a_{C} reduced accelerations for the qubit in its two contacts with the vacuum as aH=Œ±H/œâ2subscriptùëéùêªsubscriptùõºùêªsubscriptùúî2a_{H}=\alpha_{H}/\omega_{2} and aC=Œ±C/œâ1subscriptùëéùê∂subscriptùõºùê∂subscriptùúî1a_{C}=\alpha_{C}/\omega_{1} and using the general result Eq. (31), then the cyclicity condition given by Eq. (33) can be written as

Œ¥‚Äãp‚Äã(aH,p,v)+Œ¥‚Äãp‚Äã(aC,p,v)=0.ùõøùëùsubscriptùëéùêªùëùùë£ùõøùëùsubscriptùëéùê∂ùëùùë£0\delta p(a_{H},p,v)+\delta p(a_{C},p,v)=0. (38)

We also have to ensure that, during the first contact with the vacuum, the qubit has a larger energy gap œâ2subscriptùúî2\omega_{2} and that the qubit absorb heat from the vacuum fluctuations, so that Œ¥‚Äãp‚Äã(aH,p,v)>0ùõøùëùsubscriptùëéùêªùëùùë£0\delta p(a_{H},p,v)>0. This, together with the cyclic condition Eq. (38), would imply that during the second contact with the vacuum, were the qubit has a lower energy gap œâ1subscriptùúî1\omega_{1}, the vacuum acts as a thermal sink, Œ¥‚Äãp‚Äã(aC,p,v)<0ùõøùëùsubscriptùëéùê∂ùëùùë£0\delta p(a_{C},p,v)<0. Then, for the same values of pùëùp and vùë£v, but different values of reduced accelerations aHsubscriptùëéùêªa_{H} and aCsubscriptùëéùê∂a_{C}, we must ensure that the vacuum acts like a hot or cold thermal bath, respectively. In Fig. (7) we show the behavior of the absolute value of the correction |Œ¥‚Äãp|ùõøùëù|\delta p| as a function of the initial probability pùëùp, for a velocity v=0.8ùë£0.8v=0.8 and different reduced accelerations. In solid lines, we show the points where the qubit absorbs heat from the vacuum (Œ¥‚Äãp>0ùõøùëù0\delta p>0) and, in dashed lines, the points where the qubit emits heat to the vacuum (Œ¥‚Äãp<0ùõøùëù0\delta p<0). The yellow region represents the possible values of aHsubscriptùëéùêªa_{H}, aCsubscriptùëéùê∂a_{C} and pùëùp, where we can find an intersection between solid lines and dashed lines. Therefore, these regions show points corresponding to pairs of accelerations for which, by choosing the initial probability of the excited state as pùëùp, we will have a closed thermodynamic cycle and extract work from the vacuum. As an illustration, the intersection of the red solid line (aH=40subscriptùëéùêª40a_{H}=40) and the dashed orange line (aC=15subscriptùëéùê∂15a_{C}=15) occurs at the value p=0.293ùëù0.293p=0.293. This triplet satisfies Eq. (38), with v=0.8ùë£0.8v=0.8, allowing for a closed cycle in the Unruh heat engine.

In a more general analysis, Eq. (38) can be interpreted as an equation for finding the initial population of the excited state pùëùp, in such a way that the vacuum acts as a hot reservoir for the qubit with reduced acceleration aHsubscriptùëéùêªa_{H}, while at the same value of pùëùp, the vacuum acts as a cold reservoir for the qubit with reduced acceleation aCsubscriptùëéùê∂a_{C}. In this manner, we define the critical probability p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} that solves Eq. (38) as the value for our initial population such that the cycle is closed and the qubit returns to its initial state. Then, this probability, which represents intersections of solid and dashed lines in Fig.¬†7, depends on the values of the hot and cold reduced accelerations (vacuum temperatures), reading

p0=p0‚Äã(aH,aC,v).subscriptùëù0subscriptùëù0subscriptùëéùêªsubscriptùëéùê∂ùë£p_{0}=p_{0}(a_{H},a_{C},v). (39)

By using Eq. (31) into Eq.¬†(38) and defining the function

ùí´‚Äã(aH,aC,v)=2‚ÄãaH‚ãÖaC(aH+aC)‚Äãarctanh‚Å°(v)‚Äã(J‚Äã(‚àí1aH,2‚Äãarctanh‚Å°(v))+J‚Äã(‚àí1aC,2‚Äãarctanh‚Å°(v))),ùí´subscriptùëéùêªsubscriptùëéùê∂ùë£‚ãÖ2subscriptùëéùêªsubscriptùëéùê∂subscriptùëéùêªsubscriptùëéùê∂arctanhùë£ùêΩ1subscriptùëéùêª2arctanhùë£ùêΩ1subscriptùëéùê∂2arctanhùë£{\cal P}(a_{H},a_{C},v)=\frac{2a_{H}\cdot a_{C}}{(a_{H}+a_{C})\operatorname{arctanh}(v)}\left(J\left(-\frac{1}{a_{H}},2\operatorname{arctanh}(v)\right)+J\left(-\frac{1}{a_{C}},2\operatorname{arctanh}(v)\right)\right), (40)

we can shown that the solution for the initial critical probability p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} is

p0=ùí´1+2‚Äãùí´.subscriptùëù0ùí´12ùí´p_{0}=\frac{{\cal P}}{1+2{\cal P}}. (41)

The behavior of the solution given by Eq. (41) for a different pair of reduced accelerations is shown in Fig. (8a). There, we can see that 0<p0<1/20subscriptùëù0120<p_{0}<1/2, as expected from previous discussions. Now, using this solution we can define the correction Œ¥‚Äãp¬ØHùõøsubscript¬Øùëùùêª\delta\overline{p}_{H} such that

Œ¥‚Äãp¬ØH=Œ¥‚Äãp¬ØH‚Äã(aH,aC,v)=Œ¥‚Äãp‚Äã(aH,p0,v).ùõøsubscript¬Øùëùùêªùõøsubscript¬Øùëùùêªsubscriptùëéùêªsubscriptùëéùê∂ùë£ùõøùëùsubscriptùëéùêªsubscriptùëù0ùë£\delta\overline{p}_{H}=\delta\overline{p}_{H}(a_{H},a_{C},v)=\delta p(a_{H},p_{0},v). (42)

The behavior of this function is shown in Fig. (8b). There, we observe that heat is absorbed from the hot quantum vacuum, Œ¥‚Äãp¬ØH>0ùõøsubscript¬Øùëùùêª0\delta\overline{p}_{H}>0, and the cycle behaves as a thermal machine instead of a refrigerator, only when aH>aCsubscriptùëéùêªsubscriptùëéùê∂a_{H}>a_{C}, which implies in the condition

Œ±H>Œ±C‚Äã(œâ2œâ1).subscriptùõºùêªsubscriptùõºùê∂subscriptùúî2subscriptùúî1\alpha_{H}>\alpha_{C}\left(\frac{\omega_{2}}{\omega_{1}}\right). (43)

This relation is analog to the result find in Kieu04 , however in our case the role of temperatures is interpreted by the accelerations of the qubit when interacts with the vacuum fluctuations. This is in accordance with the thermal nature of the quantum vacuum predicted by Unruh. This condition, Eq. (43), is stronger that the classical relation Œ±H>Œ±Csubscriptùõºùêªsubscriptùõºùê∂\alpha_{H}>\alpha_{C}, and establish which gradients of accelerations (temperatures) could be used in order to run a quantum heat engine. Note also that we have find the initial critical probability, given by Eq. (41), in order to run the quantum thermal machine. Finally, by defining the change due to the cold reservoir as Œ¥‚Äãp¬ØC=Œ¥‚Äãp‚Äã(aC,p0,v)ùõøsubscript¬Øùëùùê∂ùõøùëùsubscriptùëéùê∂subscriptùëù0ùë£\delta\overline{p}_{C}=\delta p(a_{C},p_{0},v), we get that Œ¥‚Äãp¬ØC=‚àíŒ¥‚Äãp¬ØHùõøsubscript¬Øùëùùê∂ùõøsubscript¬Øùëùùêª\delta\overline{p}_{C}=-\delta\overline{p}_{H}, so in the domain defined by Eq. (43) we obtain that the vacuum acts like a cold reservoir when the qubit is prepare to have initial critical probability p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} and has a small reduced acceleration aCsubscriptùëéùê∂a_{C}. All this ensure us that the cycle behaves as a heat engine instead of a refrigerator.

In order to conclude our analysis, we will realize a comparison between the works performed by Unruh quantum Otto engine and the usual quantum heat engine relying on a classical thermal bath. For a classical thermal bath, we have that the work provided by the machine is given by Wc‚Äãl=(œâ2‚àíœâ1)‚ÄãŒ¥‚Äãpc‚Äãlsubscriptùëäùëêùëôsubscriptùúî2subscriptùúî1ùõøsubscriptùëùùëêùëôW_{cl}=(\omega_{2}-\omega_{1})\delta p_{cl}, where

Œ¥‚Äãpc‚Äãl=11+eŒ≤H‚Äãœâ2‚àí11+eŒ≤C‚Äãœâ1,ùõøsubscriptùëùùëêùëô11superscriptùëísubscriptùõΩùêªsubscriptùúî211superscriptùëísubscriptùõΩùê∂subscriptùúî1\delta p_{cl}=\frac{1}{1+e^{\beta_{H}\omega_{2}}}-\frac{1}{1+e^{\beta_{C}\omega_{1}}}, (44)

is the change in the population of the excited state when the qubit pass through the hot thermal bath. Here we suppose that the qubit begins this contact with an equilibrium distribution, which has a temperature given by the cold reservoir and, after this contact, the qubit state has an equilibrium distribution with temperature given by the hot reservoir. We compare our result W=(œâ2‚àíœâ1)‚ÄãŒ¥‚Äãp¬ØHùëäsubscriptùúî2subscriptùúî1ùõøsubscript¬ØùëùùêªW=(\omega_{2}-\omega_{1})\delta\overline{p}_{H} with the classical result when the temperatures TH,C=1/Œ≤H,Csubscriptùëáùêªùê∂1subscriptùõΩùêªùê∂T_{H,C}=1/\beta_{H,C} coincide with the accelerations Œ±H,Csubscriptùõºùêªùê∂\alpha_{H,C} we used here. Then, in this case, we can rewrite the classical correction in terms of the reduced accelerations

Œ¥‚Äãpc‚Äãl‚Äã(aH,aC)=11+e1/aH‚àí11+e1/aC.ùõøsubscriptùëùùëêùëôsubscriptùëéùêªsubscriptùëéùê∂11superscriptùëí1subscriptùëéùêª11superscriptùëí1subscriptùëéùê∂\delta p_{cl}(a_{H},a_{C})=\frac{1}{1+e^{1/a_{H}}}-\frac{1}{1+e^{1/a_{C}}}. (45)

Since, our correction Œ¥‚Äãp¬ØH‚Äã(aH,aC,v)ùõøsubscript¬Øùëùùêªsubscriptùëéùêªsubscriptùëéùê∂ùë£\delta\overline{p}_{H}(a_{H},a_{C},v) also depends on the velocity of the qubit in the kinematic cycle, we can compare this correction for different values of the qubit velocity versus the classical thermal bath correction. This is shown in Fig. (9). There we can see that, as we increase the qubit velocity vùë£v in the quantum Unruh heat engine, the results approach the expected result of a classical thermal bath. This can be understood in terms of the interaction time with the vacuum. Since we are dealing with a finite trajectory in space-time, the interaction time of the qubit with the vacuum fluctuations is finite and given by ùíØ=2‚Äãarctanh‚Å°(v)/Œ±ùíØ2arctanhùë£ùõº{\cal T}=2\operatorname{arctanh}(v)/\alpha. So, as we increase the qubit velocity, the interaction time with the vacuum fluctuations also increases and we approach a classical thermal equilibrium. It is worth noting here that perturbation theory constrains us to small values of ùíØùíØ{\cal T}, so very small values of Œ±ùõº\alpha as well as ultrahigh velocities v‚âà1ùë£1v\approx 1 must be avoided.

6 Conclusions

We have introduced a relativistic quantum thermal machine based on the Unruh effect. This is achieved by taking the quantum vaccuum as a thermal reservoir. By using quasi-static processes and perturbation theory, we are then able to establish the conditions over the initial excitation probability p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} and qubit accelerations aHsubscriptùëéùêªa_{H} and aCsubscriptùëéùê∂a_{C} for ensuring closed cycles, both from the thermodynamic and kinematic point of view. More specifically, we determine sets of triplets (p0,aH,aC)subscriptùëù0subscriptùëéùêªsubscriptùëéùê∂(p_{0},a_{H},a_{C}) such that a closed cycle emerges. Moreover, we have also shown that the classical efficiency of the Otto cycle persists in the relativistic regime, suggesting a universal bound as long as quasi-static processes are adopted. On the other hand, work is nontrvially affected by kinematics, being dependent on the velocities and accelerations of the qubit throughout its time evolution. This analysis has been analytically provided via perturbation theory, with its limitations delineated.

Even though realizations of the Unruh effect are still challenging, the thermal machine proposed here opens the possibility of posing relativistic quantum themodynamics in an experimental setting for quantum motors and refrigerators as long as alternative approaches¬†Felicetti:15 ; Laguna:17 ; Wang:14 ; Ahluwalia:16 ; Cozzella:17 ; Crispino:08 for probing the Unruh effect are well-succeeded. As further developments, it remains the extension of our approach to the non-equilibrium regime in open systems, e.g., with the entropy production taken into account¬†Deffner:11 . Moreover, it is still promising the investigation of the role of correlations, such as entanglement, for the machine efficiency. These topics are left for future research.

Appendix B Regularization by Lorentzian profile

In this appendix, we will show more explicitly how the vacuum fluctuations transfer heat to the qubit system. The integral that shows the connection between vacuum fluctuations and the specific trajectory of the qubit is given by

ùí•‚Äã(Œ±,œâ,ùíØ)=‚à´‚àíùíØ/2ùíØ/2ùëëœÑ‚Äã‚à´‚àíùíØ/2ùíØ/2ùëëœÑ‚Ä≤‚Äãei‚Äãœâ‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãœÑ‚ÄãGŒ±+‚Äã(œÑ,œÑ‚Ä≤).ùí•ùõºùúîùíØsuperscriptsubscriptùíØ2ùíØ2differential-dùúèsuperscriptsubscriptùíØ2ùíØ2differential-dsuperscriptùúè‚Ä≤superscriptùëíùëñùúîŒîùúèsubscriptsuperscriptùê∫ùõºùúèsuperscriptùúè‚Ä≤{\cal J}(\alpha,\omega,{\cal T})=\int_{-{\cal T}/2}^{{\cal T}/2}d\tau\int_{-{\cal T}/2}^{{\cal T}/2}d\tau^{\prime}e^{i\omega\Delta\tau}G^{+}_{\alpha}(\tau,\tau^{\prime}). (B.1)

Here, the finite-time interval ùíØùíØ{\cal T} is defined in terms of the velocity vùë£v and the acceleration Œ±ùõº\alpha. This finite-time integral can be extended to infinite by using a regulator that is compact in the domain we are interested in and vanish outside. This procedure is in the same spirit of the regularization by a cut-off function of an infinite divergent integral. In particular, finite-time integrals related to the Unruh effect have been previously analyzed, e.g., in Refs.¬†Svaiter:92 ; Matsas:93 . However, since we are dealing with a kinematically closed trajectory there is no need of taking the limit of infinite time. Hence, we will identify Eq. (B.1) with the expression

ùí•‚Äã(Œ±,œâ,ùíØ)=‚à´‚àí‚àû‚àûùëëœÑ‚Äã‚à´‚àí‚àû‚àûùëëœÑ‚Ä≤‚ÄãŒæùíØ‚Äã(œÑ)‚ÄãŒæùíØ‚Äã(œÑ‚Ä≤)‚Äãei‚Äãœâ‚ÄãŒî‚ÄãœÑ‚ÄãGŒ±+‚Äã(œÑ,œÑ‚Ä≤),ùí•ùõºùúîùíØsuperscriptsubscriptdifferential-dùúèsuperscriptsubscriptdifferential-dsuperscriptùúè‚Ä≤subscriptùúâùíØùúèsubscriptùúâùíØsuperscriptùúè‚Ä≤superscriptùëíùëñùúîŒîùúèsubscriptsuperscriptùê∫ùõºùúèsuperscriptùúè‚Ä≤{\cal J}(\alpha,\omega,{\cal T})=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}d\tau\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}d\tau^{\prime}\xi_{\cal T}(\tau)\xi_{\cal T}(\tau^{\prime})e^{i\omega\Delta\tau}G^{+}_{\alpha}(\tau,\tau^{\prime}), (B.2)

where ŒæùíØ‚Äã(œÑ)subscriptùúâùíØùúè\xi_{\cal T}(\tau) is a compact smooth function that is nonvanishing for ‚àíùíØ/2<œÑ<ùíØ/2ùíØ2ùúèùíØ2-{\cal T}/2<\tau<{\cal T}/2, being approximately zero outside that domain. We could try to adopt a Gaussian regulator of the kind Œæg‚Äãa‚Äãu‚Äãs‚Äãs‚àºexp‚Å°(‚àíœÑ2/ùíØ2)similar-tosubscriptùúâùëîùëéùë¢ùë†ùë†superscriptùúè2superscriptùíØ2\xi_{gauss}\sim\exp(-\tau^{2}/{\cal T}^{2}). However, as we expand this Gaussian regulator to the complex plane œÑ‚Üíz‚àà‚ÑÇ‚Üíùúèùëß‚ÑÇ\tau\rightarrow z\in\mathbb{C}, we see that it does not vanish for any |z|‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëß|z|\rightarrow\infty. Actually, depending on the phase in z=|z|‚Äãei‚ÄãŒ∏ùëßùëßsuperscriptùëíùëñùúÉz=|z|e^{i\theta}, this regulator can be divergent. In order to bypass this difficulty, we adopt as a regulator ŒæùíØ‚Äã(œÑ)subscriptùúâùíØùúè\xi_{\cal T}(\tau) a Lorentzian profile rather than a Gaussian profile, i.e.

ŒæùíØ‚Äã(œÑ)=(ùíØ/2)2œÑ2+(ùíØ/2)2.subscriptùúâùíØùúèsuperscriptùíØ22superscriptùúè2superscriptùíØ22\xi_{\cal T}(\tau)=\frac{({\cal T}/2)^{2}}{\tau^{2}+({\cal T}/2)^{2}}. (B.3)

The expression above for ŒæùíØ‚Äã(œÑ)subscriptùúâùíØùúè\xi_{\cal T}(\tau) yields

ŒæùíØ‚Äã(œÑ)‚ÄãŒæùíØ‚Äã(œÑ‚Ä≤)=ùíØ4(T2‚àíT12)‚Äã(T2‚àíT22),subscriptùúâùíØùúèsubscriptùúâùíØsuperscriptùúè‚Ä≤superscriptùíØ4superscriptùëá2superscriptsubscriptùëá12superscriptùëá2superscriptsubscriptùëá22\xi_{\cal T}(\tau)\xi_{\cal T}(\tau^{\prime})=\frac{{\cal T}^{4}}{(T^{2}-T_{1}^{2})(T^{2}-T_{2}^{2})}, (B.4)

where we have defined T1=Œî‚ÄãœÑ+i‚ÄãùíØsubscriptùëá1ŒîùúèùëñùíØT_{1}=\Delta\tau+i{\cal T} and T2=‚àíŒî‚ÄãœÑ+i‚ÄãùíØsubscriptùëá2ŒîùúèùëñùíØT_{2}=-\Delta\tau+i{\cal T}. Hence, Eq. (B.4) shows ŒæùíØ‚Äã(œÑ)‚ÄãŒæùíØ‚Äã(œÑ‚Ä≤)subscriptùúâùíØùúèsubscriptùúâùíØsuperscriptùúè‚Ä≤\xi_{\cal T}(\tau)\xi_{\cal T}(\tau^{\prime}) explicitly as a function of T=œÑ+œÑ‚Ä≤ùëáùúèsuperscriptùúè‚Ä≤T=\tau+\tau^{\prime}. This function posses a pole structure in the complex plane of TùëáT, as shown in Fig. (10). Naturally, the polar structure depends on Œî‚ÄãœÑ=œÑ‚àíœÑ‚Ä≤Œîùúèùúèsuperscriptùúè‚Ä≤\Delta\tau=\tau-\tau^{\prime}.

Now, performing the change of integration variables from (œÑ,œÑ‚Ä≤)ùúèsuperscriptùúè‚Ä≤(\tau,\tau^{\prime}) to (T,Œî‚ÄãœÑ)ùëáŒîùúè(T,\Delta\tau) one gets
